title: Corrections & Amplifications

title: Another Day, Another Huge Off-Market Sale for Aspen's High-End Home Market

description: The football coach had been suspended after public revelation of a complaint against him from an activist hired by the university to provide education on sexual misconduct.

What the Board Needs to Know
description: Everything from the week beginning Sept. 18, 2023, that a corporate board director needs to know ahead of a board meeting. This week we look at the attacks against two large casinos and the disruption they caused. Plus: minimizing cyber risks ahead of layoffs; the latest cybersecurity and privacy regulations; and advice for high-profile individuals seeking to secure their online accounts.

title: California Companies Defer Billions in Taxes, Interest-Free, as Borrowing Costs Rise
description: Thanks to disaster relief offered by the IRS, companies in California have been allowed to put off this year’s federal tax payments until October. It’s helped plump some balance sheets.

title: iOS 17 Is Here. Apple's iPhone Update Improves Calls, Messages, Autocorrect and More.

description: SocGen has targeted a return on tangible equity of 9%-10% in 2026, and forecast lower average annual revenue growth for the 2022-2026 period, as it aims to streamline its portfolio and reduce oil-and-gas exposure.

title: Limited Issuance Seen Supportive For Finnish Government Bonds
description: Very limited supply in Finnish government bonds for the rest of 2023 will be a supportive factor, with their main challenge being that it is a small market with lower liquidity versus large issuers, Danske Bank Research said.

title: U.K. House Prices Post Modest Monthly Rise
description: The average house price in the U.K. rose 0.4% in the month to Sept. 9, amid sluggish activity in the market, with interest-rate rises and summer holidays leading to price reductions not seen since January 2011.

title: China Evergrande Shares Dip After Police Detain Some Wealth-Management Unit Staff
description: China Evergrande Group’s shares dipped after police in southern China detained some staff at its wealth-management unit, adding to the debt-laden developer’s woes.
